titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. VI. Thursday.

lg.l: The fate of Midian let them meet
Like Sisera’s doom at Kison’s well—
Like Oreb and like Zeeb treat
Their nobles, who at Endor fell
Like Zeba and Zalmunna slay
Prostrate in dust their princely powers
Their proudest Peers who dared to say
Make we Jehovah’s Mansions ours.
Sweep them O God like dust away
Before the wind as stubble flies
As fires upon the forest prey
And kindling Mountains brave the skies
Thus let thy Tempest on them fall
Their faces cover thus with shame
Thus let thy storm their hearts appal
That they, O God, may seek thy name.

div.p: Called on Mrs Tudor at her request— She wants proof that her husband was an Officer in the War of the Revolution. H.R.U.S. Clayton’s Resolution for a Committee to investigate the Affairs of the Bank U:S. T. R. Mitchell—H. Denny, Watmough, Foster of Georgia—Cambreleng.—Watmough Offers an Amendment— M’Duffie surrenders the whole Question— Adjourn at four O’Clock—
[symbols]
Apportionment Bill in the Senate. Webster’s Speech.
2. V. Friday.

lg.l: Shame and confusion be their doom
Afflict with trouble all their days
Their substance let thy wrath consume
And let them perish in their ways
Then shall the race of mortals know
In homage kneeling at thy throne
In Heaven on high and Earth below
That thou art God—and thou alone

div.p: Psalm 84.

lg.l: Thy Tents— How lovely, Lord, they be—
O, how I long with thee to dwell
My flesh, my heart cries out for thee
What tongue my Soul’s desires can tell—
The Sparrow nestles at thy shrine
And there the swallow smooths her wing
The mansions of their young are thine,
Oh Lord of Hosts, my God and King.

div.p: at the Navy Department— Saw Mr Woodbury— Has ordered payment of 48000. dollars of the claim of Jonathan Newcomb &c and will order payment of the rest— At the War Department— Left Hodge’s Letter— House Clayton’s Bank Resolution. He made half his speech— Pass’d to orders of the day. Bill for Mrs Decatur’s relief. Comee. of the whole—J. Davis—an hour and a half.— Carson half an hour— M’Duffie moves Committee to rise—adjourned at 4. John dined at Mr J. L. Kerr’s. I wrote to Newcomb, Richards and Gridley. Walk and Conversation with R. M. Johnson.
3. VI. Saturday.

lg.l: Blest they who in thy house abide
And from thy altar incense raise—
Of whom thy glory forms the pride
Whose hearts delight in Zion’s ways.
To them, the dreariest vale of tears,
Turns to refreshing showers of rain—
To them in Zion God appears
Nor shall they plead to him in vain.
O, God of Jacob, hear my prayer—
Thine own anointed, Lord, behold—
One day within thy Courts to share
Is Joy, is bliss a thousand fold—
Yes— I had rather at thy door
Stand than in wicked Tents to dwell,
Thy grace, thy glory I implore
Thy joys what mortal tongue can tell?

div.p: at the House— Clayton’s Resolution—whether to be discussed this day or on Monday after debate postponed— Bill for relief of Susan Decatur. M’Duffie—P. L. Tracy. Elutheros Cook— Committee rose at half past four, and the house adjourned. T. Newton in the Library introduced General Taylor of Norfolk Mrand Mr Lambert. Note from R M Johnson Noyes Barbour, Elutheros Cook Bates Cook, John Holmes. Richard Peters— John Sergeant. William B. Shepperd. Philemon Thomas— Joseph M Vance— George A. Waggaman and Frederick Whittlesey dined with us— Saw Mr Southard.
4. VI. Sunday— Psalm 85.

lg.l: Lord, to thy People thou art kind
And Jacob’s captives has restor’d—
His sons from thee forgiveness find
Nor have in vain thy grace implor’d
Thy wrath has vanished all away:
Thine Anger melted into Peace—
Salvation’s God—to thee we pray
O, cause thy burning wrath to cease
Lord—shall thy wrath forever last?
Thine Anger to all Time endure?
Redeem us from transgressions past.
And let thy People dwell secure.
Turn us, O God, and let us live
Redeem the People of thy choice
Salvations God our Sins forgive
And let us in thy name rejoice.

div.p: With Mrs Adams at St. John’s Church— Heard Mr Keith of Alexandria, Quinquagesima Sunday— Revelations 3:20. Mrs Tudor here— In the afternoon heard Mr Smith about 30 persons at Church. Rain—he made two prayers and commented upon two hymns which he gave out to be sung.
5. V. Monday.

lg.l: Hark— I will hear what God shall say
He to his People, Peace shall speak—
But let the Servants of his sway
Let them no more to Folly seek
His Saints, Salvation’s joy shall greet—
The Land in Glory shall exist.
Mercy and Truth together meet
And Peace and Righteousness have kiss’d.
Yes—from Earth’s bosom Truth shall spring
And Righteousness from Heaven look down
The Lord himself shall be our king
And with increase the Land shall crown.
Jehovah Plenty shall bestow
And good with bounteous hand provide
Before him Righteousness shall go
And in his way her footsteps guide

div.p: Rode to H.R.U.S. Petitions called for. I presented Memorial from New-York—concerning the Cherokee Indians, and the imprisoned Missionaries. Read. Moved its reference to a select Committee— Bills for reference to Committee on Indian Affairs— To lay on the Table negatived 92 to 91. J. Davis moves reference to Committee of the whole on the State of the Union. A. Stewarts previous Question— Wickliffe on question to commit—carried 96 to 93. Then referred without division to the Committee of the whole on the state of the Union. Adjourned.
6. V. Tuesday.— Psalm 86.

lg.l: Incline thine ear, O Lord, and hear—
For I am poor and in distress—
To thee, my worship is sincere
O save thy Servant, Lord—and bless.
Be merciful, O God, to me
For daily, unto thee I cry
Rejoice my Soul; for unto thee,
O Lord, I lift my Soul on high
Lord thou art ready to forgive
Them who on thee for Mercy call
Lord, to my voice attention give
Nor let my supplication fall.
To thee, in trouble I will run
And thou will answer to my prayer—
Like thee among the Gods is none
Nor works that may with thine compare

div.p: J. S. Hastings here— H.R.U.S. Petitions called by States—from Massachusetts, where they were yesterday left—through the list.
Reports from Standing Comees
Reports from Select Comees.

Mr Clayton’s Resolution for a Committee to investigate the affairs of U.S. Bank— He spoke upwards of three hours, an infinite deal of nothing.— Adjourned at half past four.— Mrs W. S. Smith dined with us— Apportionment Bill in the Senate— Saw Mr Webster— Wrote to J. Connell and to Jos. Blunt.
7. V.15. Wednesday— Ash

lg.l: The Nations, all whom thou hast made
Shall come, and at thine altar bow
There shall thy glory be display’d—
For thou art God, and only thou.
O Lord how great art thou in deed
Thy power Creation’s work proclaim
O let me in thy Truth proceed
Unite my heart to fear thy name.
O Lord my God the voice of praise
To thee shall from my heart ascend
The Song of glory I will raise
For thou art my almighty friend
My Soul, redeeming Mercy draws
Up from the lowest depths of Hell
The proud, O God, despise thy Laws
Against thee, lawless Men rebel.

div.p: Attended the Committee on Manufactures— Horn J. S. Barbour and Dayan present— Dr. Condict, Findlay and Worthington absent. J. S. Hastings and J. S Wright there— Read two Memorials and Statements H.R.U.S.

Clayton’s Resolution. Root’s Speech for Committee of 7. by Ballot— Crawford and Evans— Then Beardsley. Violent attack upon Root adjourned after 4— Beardsley not finished— Answer to N. Biddle— Mrs Tudor called on me this Evening.
8. V:45. Thursday.

lg.l: They seek my life, O god, but thou
Art gracious, merciful and kind
O save me; let thy Servant now
Some token of thy favour find
Lord to thy handmaid’s Son impart
Thy Strength—let all who hate me see
That thou my sure Protector art
And all my comfort flows from thee

div.p: Psalm 87.

lg.l: Mountain of glory, on thy crest
The Temple of Jehovah stands
Ye holy gates of Zion—blest
Beyond the choice of Jacob’s lands
City of God—what joy is thine
What glorious things of thee are told
Rahab and Babylon are mine
Tyre and Philistia, mine behold.

div.p: H.R.US.— Clayton’s Bank investigation Resolution—
Beardsley finished his speech. Root replied— Personalities. Bell of Tennessee’s Speech. Opinions of P.U.S.

Root’s Amendment, for a Committee of 7. to be chosen by ballot rejected by yeas and nays 92 to 88. 15 or 16 skulkers— Wayne proposes a long amendment. Burges another overshingling it. House adjourns after 4. I called this morning on Heyward, Commissioner of the Land Office, for Mrs Tudor. She sent for me this Evening— She proposes to petition Congress for bounty Lands and commutation pay. P. L. Tracy here with Perkins of Connt. and Dr. Henry of New-York.
9. VI.15. Friday.

lg.l: God of Salvation
Not Ethiopia’s self shall fail
A worshipper of mine to yield—
But Zion’s numbers shall prevail
The most high God shall be her shield.
Her Sons in countless numbers born
She to the Lord of hosts shall bring—
She tunes the voice—she fills the horn—
From thee my fountains all shall spring.

div.p: Psalm 88.

lg.l: God of Salvation— Night and day
My knees in supplication bend—
O God of Mercy—hear me pray—
O let my cries to thee ascend
My Soul consumes with scorching fires
My life draws near the narrow bed
My strength in impotence expires—
And I am number’d with the dead.

div.p: Committee on Manufactures— Dr Condict, Dayan and Horn— Read the Letters and draught of Bill from the Secy of the Treasury— Abolition of the Minimums— All the members present against it— I am to draught a bill— Adjourn’d till next Tuesday.— H.R.U.S.— Clayton’s Resolution— Wayne’s Amendmt Burges’s—Super amendment Clashing between Wayne, and G. M’Duffie— Barstow moves reconsideration—of yesterday’s vote—carried 98 to 93. Amendments to be printed. Bill for Susan Decatur— Reported to the House— Davis’s Amendment—and Pearce’s and the Bill rejected.
10. IV:30. Saturday.

lg.l: Free, like the slain, of whom we know
Thy grace no more remembrance keeps
By thine avenging hand laid low
In darkness, in the lowest deeps
Dash’d by thy tempest waves along
By all my former friends forget—
Lord, thou hast made of me their song—
And helpless bondage is my lot.
I lift my hands, I raise mine eyes
To thee, and streams of Sorrow shed
To praise thee, shall the dead arise?
Wilt thou show wonders to the dead?
Thy goodness shall the grave proclaim?
Shall death thy righteousness display
Shall Night illuminate thy fame?
Or dark Oblivion spread thy sway?

div.p: Call on the Secretary of War.—L. Cass— Spoke of Mrs Tudor’s claim— He said she had sent for him yesterday, and he was causing all the facts to be examined—
H.R.U.S.— Resolution for purchasing 240 copies of History of Bank U.S. reported by Library Committee— Barringer moves an Amendment—yeas and nays twice taken— Resolution carried 95 to 80.

Post-Office Bill passed— Doddridge moved a reconsideration of the rejection of Bill for Susan Decatur— Adjourned 2.30 George Burd, Lewis Condict. E. Everett and Mrs C. J. Ingersoll— Horatio Seymour and Mrs S. L. Southard and Virginia. Isaac Southard and Jared Sparks dined here— Letter from Connell—
11. V:30. Sunday.

lg.l: To thee, Jehovah, have I cried
To thee my morning prayers ascend
Thy face, O wherefore dost thou hide?
Why cast me off, O God, my friend.
In deep affliction and distress
From Youth to Age, my life has past—
Nor can the power of words express
The terrors of thy vengeful blast.
Distraction seizes on my Soul
Thy wrath pursues me to the grave
Around me raging billows roll
Sunk in the overwhelming wave.
In vain to thee my hands I raise
Of every comforter bereft—
For not, to cheer my closing days
One friend or lover has thou left.

div.p: Rain— Heard Mr Smith from John 8.56.
David Hoffman J. S. Barrell, and W. B. Hodgson here— Going to Constantinople as Dragoman.
Rain

That at what Time ye hear the sound of the cornet, flute, harp, sackbut, psaltery, dulcimer and all kinds of musick, ye fall down and worship the golden image that Nebuchadnezzar the king hath set up Daniel 3.5.
12. V:15. Monday. Psalm 89.

lg.l: Jehovah’s Mercies I will sing
And make to after ages known
His Mercy’s never-failing Spring
Flows at the footstep of his throne
“A chosen Covenant I have made
And to my Servant David sworn.
By thee the Sceptre shall be sway’d
Thy throne for ages be upborn.”
The Heavens, thy wonders, Lord, shall see
Thy Saints assembled speak thy word—
Who in the Heavens is like to thee?
Who, of the mighty, like the Lord?
Our God, is greatly to be fear’d
Girt round with faithfulness divine—
By all the assembled Saints rever’d—
Lord God of Hosts what power is thine!

div.p: At the House— Petitions called for— The Bill for relief of Susan Decatur postponed till next Friday— Boon of Indiana moved that the House should in future meet every morning at 11. Objected to by Whittlesey Laid upon the Table— Clayton’s Bank Resolution— Leavitt of Ohio speech against the chair by Ballot.— Daniel of Kentucky in favour of it. Angel of New-York’s lamentations over Root. Jenifer’s Speech about federalism and federalists— Collier moves an adjournment—
Thunder and Hail-Storm.
13. IV:30. Tuesday.

lg.l: Thy voice the raging of the Sea
Obeys—it calms the stormy wave.
The proud are prostrate laid by thee
Thy arm no mortal might can brave.
The Heavens are thine, the Earth is thine
The world, its fulness thee proclaim
North, South confess thy hand divine
Tabor and Hermon shout thy name.
Thy arm how strong?— how high thy hand
Justice and Judgment fill thy throne
Before thee Truth and Mercy stand—
Thou art our glory—thou alone
Blest, all who know thy Trumpets’ sound,
And hear the cheering of thy voice—
They in thy Justice shall be crown’d
And ceaseless in thy name rejoice

div.p: Committee on Manufactures. Condict—Horn, Dayan, Worthington— Findlay and Barbour absent. Draught of Bill discuss’d—to meet to-morrow.
House— Clayton’s Resolution— Root’s Amendment. Collier. M’Duffie— I gave notice of amendment. Call of the House— Question on Root’s Amendment 100 vs 100. Speaker decided against it.
Wayne’s Amendmt. His Speech unfinished Adjourned 1/4 past 4. Drayton’s remark on Wayne
14. VI.30. Wednesday.

lg.l: To us thy favour is reveal’d
From thee our daily blessings spring
The Lord Jehovah is our shield
And Israels holy one our king
In vision thou to him didst say
My help on David I have laid
My chosen Sceptre he shall sway
Him, my anointed—I have made
My hand his firm support shall prove
To him my promise shall be true
His Soul no wicked man shall move
His might no Enemy subdue
Before him I will drive his foe;
Beneath my feet his hater tread.
With him my Faithfulness shall go
And in my name exalt his head.

div.p: Committee on Manufactures Condict, Dayan, Horn Worthington present. Findlay & Barbour absent. Draught of Bill discussed— To meet again to-morrow. Wayne finished his Speech. His amendment rejected by yeas and nays.

Hubbard moves previous question to cut off my amendment—and call of the House— House calld Previous question not seconded— My Amendment taken up— Amendments moved by Beardsley Hogan and Howard; all rejected by yeas and nays. my amendment carried by yeas and nays 105 to 93. Committee of 7. House adjourned at half past 5 in the Evening
15. V:15. Thursday.

lg.l: His hand shall stretch beyond the Sea
To him the streaming floods shall flock
“My God”—shall be his cry to me
My father—my Salvation’s Rock
Of him, my first born I will make
O’er all the Monarchs of the Land
Him shall my Mercy ne’er forsake—
With him my Covenant shall stand
His soul forever shall remain
Long as the Heavens his throne shall last
But should they make my Statutes vain
And from them my Commandments cast
Ay—should his Sons forsake their God
And slight the rock of their defence
Then will I persist with the rod
And stripes shall punish their offence.

div.p: Hayward Comr Land-Office concerning Mrs Tudors Claim— Radcliff Wm Isthmus of Panama Railway— Commee. on Manufactures—Dayan—Horn—present. No Quorum my draught of Bill discussed. H.R.U.S.
Root’s Resolution for Amendment Constitution U.S. referred to Comee. Whole on State of the Union.
Appropriation Bills debate on Republic of Columbia. Turkish Treaty &c Bills reported I asked to be excused from Comee. on Manufactures— Lane this Eve with Letter from D. Webster
16. V:45. Friday

lg.l: Him shall my favour not forsake
My loving kindness shall prevail
My love . . . I will not break
Nor shall one word I utter’d fail
Once by my Holiness I swore
And shall I false to David prove?
His seed till Time shall be no more
Shall last—his throne no Time shall move
“Fixed as the witness in the skies
While Sun and Moon their races run.”
But wherefore doth thine Anger rise?
Lord, what hath thine anointed done?
Void, thy own Covenant is made
Lo! prostrate in the dust his Crown
His Strong holds all in ruin laid
And all his Hedges broken down

div.p: Bank Committee— Present Clayton Adams, M’Duffie, R. M. Johnson, Cambreleng, Thomas, Watmough. To go to Philadelphia next week— To consult precedents of the former Committee— To meet to-morrow— Committee on Manufactures— Condict Dayan Worthington absent Findlay, Horn and J. S. Barbour. My draught of Bill further discussed— To meet Monday. H.R.U.S.— I asked to be excused from Comee on Manufactures—debate— Appropriation Bill— My Speech on item for the Turkish Negotiation— Adjourned near to 6 PM— W Radclif Rail road across the Isthmus of Panama Letters from my brother, wife and daughter Elizabeth and J Marston.
17. V. Saturday—

lg.l: The spoil of all who pass him by
Of all his neighbours made the jest;
His foes thou hast exalted high
His enemies with triumph blast
His falchion edgeless thou hast made
In battle recreant he is found:
His glory thou hast caus’d to fade
And cast his throne upon the ground.
Thy hand hath shown his youthful Space
Thou, Lord, hast covered him with shame
How long wilt thou conceal thy face?
How long shall burn thy angers flame?
How short my time—how frail my breath
Why hast thou made in vain mankind?
What living man shall not see death?
Who—refuge from the grave shall find?

div.p: Bank investigation Committee Arrangements for proceeding to Philadelphia. Clayton goes with his family— Thomas by the way of Frederick—5—to go in a Carriage which I engaged to furnish— H.R.U.S.

Appropriation Bill passed. Enquiry moved by Wickliffe against Hayward—referred to Judiciary Committee— Adjourned between 2 and 3— Letter from Charles My brother died last Monday the 12th. Call on D. Webster— Excuses to Clay and Pendleton. Snow-Storm.
18. V:30. Sunday— Fahrenheit 12.

lg.l: Where has thy loving-kindness fled
Once, by thy Truth to David sworn?
Lord; in thy footsteps while I tread
I hear of multitudes the scorn
Yet shalt thy name, by me ador’d
Defy the taunts of wicked men—
Forever praised be the Lord—
Amen—forever and Amen—

div.p: Psalm 90

lg.l: Lord—ere the Mountains came to birth
When first created by thy nod
Or ever thou hadst form’d the Earth—
Thou from Eternity art God.
But man a worm of dust appears
By thee to swift destruction cast
For in thy sight a thousand years,
Are but as yesterday when past

div.p: Heard Smith. 1. Romans 18 Hebrews 13.15.
Hassler F. R.— His Son
Nicolét— Genl. Macomb.
J. Davis— N. Appleton.
19. V:30: Monday

lg.l: Thou sweepst them as a flood away
They flourish and they fade like grass
Bloom with the moon at eve decay
And spring and wither as they pass
We perish in thy Anger’s flame
And vainly from thy wrath would flee
Before thee, thou hast set our shame
Our secret Sins are known to thee
Thy wrath consumes the sons of men—
Our lives a worthless waste unfold—
Our days are three score years and ten
We spend them as a Tale is told.
Should strength e’en four-score years supply
They pass in weakness and in woe.
Too soon cut off—away we fly
Lord—who thine Angers power can know?

div.p: Committee on Manufactures. Condict, Horn, Dayan Worthington present. Barbour there a few minutes— Read my draught of a Bill— Horn intractable. House— Petitions and Resolutions— Bills on third reading— Appropriation Bill passed— Insolvent debtors Bill— Judge Baldwin— Call on D. Webster in Comee. Room Apportionment Bill—Tariff
Evening—N. Frye—Judge Baldwin and T. R. Mitchell successively here— Baldwin spoke of Wilkins.
20. V:15. Tuesday.

lg.l: Thine indignation who reveres?
Teach us to number thus our days.
O Lord, how long?—dispel our fears—
And turn our hearts to Wisdom’s ways.
Return, Jehovah— Smile once more
Nor longer on thy Servants frown.
Call us, thy Mercies to adore
And all our days with gladness crown—
As thine afflicting hand we felt
So let our days of gladness gleam
Be mercy to thy Servants dealt
Shed on their Sons thy glory’s beam.
Lord let thy favour on us shine
O Lord our God our labours bless.
Cheer us with energy divine
Yea, crown our labours with success—

div.p: Committee on Manufactures. Condict, J. S. Barbour—Dayan, Horn, Worthington— Agreed to report a Bill on Revenue Frauds— Horn dissentient. Bank Committee— Agreed to go at one to-morrow.
H.R.U.S.— Perry—a Clerk copies my Bill.
Wilde of Georgia. Resolution upon gold Coins. Bill relief of insolvent debtor of U.S— M’Duffie’s Amendments— Bill passed to third reading.

Resolutions for Paintings in the Rotundo— Question of consideration made by J. W. Taylor yeas and nays 76 to 80. rejected— Peyton Gay— Shannon going to Guatimala— Mrs Tudor sent for me this Evening— Letter from Charles answered
21. V:15. Wednesday— Psalm 91.— From Washington to Baltimore.

lg.l: He whom thy secret place shall hide
Dwells in the shadow of the just
Thou art my refuge and my pride—
My Rock—my God—in whom I trust.
Safe from the wily fowler’s snare—
From noisome pestilence conceal’d
His wings shall cover thee with care
His Truth, thy buckler prove, and shield.
Dread not the fear, by Night that walks
Nor flying shaft that thirsts for prey—
The Pestilence in darkness walks
Destruction wasteth at Noon day.
Fear not—around thee thousands fall—
Ten thousand sink before thine eyes.
Unhurt shalt thou behold it all
And see the foul transgressor’s prize

div.p: Committee on Manufactures. Condict, Horn, J. S. Barbour, Dayan, Worthington present. Read my Fragments.
H.R.U.S. Reported from the Committee, Bill for prevention of Frauds on the Revenue. Withdrew my request to be excused.

Stage (Belzhoover’s) came to the door of the House at one. M’Duffie, R. M. Johnson, Cambreleng, Watmough and myself left the House at 1.15. and came to Baltimore. Dined at Rossburg— Lodge at Barnum’s— Judge Clayton, and Mr Thomas called in the course of the Evening— J. S. Skinner, Gibson, and Mr Buchanan.
22. V. Thursday— From Baltimore to Philadelphia

lg.l: Though Lord art my protection still
Thy mansion thou hast set on high
To thee shall happen nothing ill
Nor plague approach thy dwelling nigh.
His Angels charge of thee shall take
By him commission’d from his throne—
So shalt thou not thy path mistake—
Nor dash thy foot against a stone.
The dragon’s den—the Lion’s Lair,
The Adder’s fang shalt thou despise
His Life shall be my special care—
Because his Soul on me relies.
Yes, I will hear him when he prays
With him in trouble I will be.
My grace shall grant him length of days
And my Salvation he shall see.

div.p: Rose at 5. Steamer Carroll of Carrollton at half past six. French-town at half past eleven— Mrs Clayton, and Mrs Constant. Govr. Findley. Mr Townsend of New-York. Rail-road Cars from Frenchtown to Newcastle. there at One— Steamer Robert Morris Captain Douglass— Philadelphia at 4. P.M.— United States Hotel. Meeting of the Committee. Clerk to be appointed. Notice to be given by the Chairman to President of the Bank. Question as to the charge of subsidizing the Press— My objection to trying and censuring individuals unheard—questions postponed— Invitations to an Evening party this Evening at Mrs John Sergeant— Johnson, M’Duffie; Cambreleng and Thomas went to the Theatre. Evening visits from Mr Watson, J. Connell and Coll. T. L. M’Kenney.
Psalm. 92

lg.l: Tis a good thing to thank the Lord—
To bid his praises tune the string
At Morning dawn, his love record
And of his Truth at Eve to sing.
Let Harp and Lute and Horn resound
Thy glories through thy works expand
My heart exulting shall rebound—
And praise the wonders of thy hand.

div.p: 23. VI:30. Friday.

lg.l: O Lord, how glorious are thy deeds
How deep thy purposes descend
But this, the scorner never heeds
The stupid cannot comprehend.
For when the wicked seem to rise
And flourish in the bloom of Spring
Tis but their Ruin in Disguise
And thou art still Creation’s king.
See how they perish—all thy foes
Behold destruction oer them spread
The while my Horn with plenty flows
And holy oil, anoints my head
Mine eyes their ruin shall behold
Their hapless fate has reach’d my ears
The just shall blooming psalms unfold
As Lebanon her cedars rear

div.p: Committee at 9. After breakfast Notice to President of the Bank his answer— Committee went to the Bank— Met N. Biddle President— Horace Binney, T. Cadwalader and Manual Eyre— Biddle’s exposition of the Affairs of the Bank— Short and comprehensive— Committee returned to their chamber— Adjourn. Appointed W. B. Reed as Clerk. Walk— Met Hopkinson— Went to the Mint—a handsome Marble Ionic order building— At Mr Hopkinson’s Met R Walsh and Miss Mease—James Brown— Committee met again at two. Mr Clayton produced his manuscript charges and new ones. Adjourned again to five scrutinized . . . the short Evening Meeting Call in the Evening on S. L. Southard and John Sergeant. Committee decline invitations.
24. V.45. Saturday.

lg.l: Yes, planted in the House of God—
There they shall flourish and take root
And rising verdant from the sod
Bear in old age abundant fruit.
Then shall the race of man confess
The Lord Jehovah to be just—
Then shall they learn his name to bless
And put in him alone their trust.

div.p: Committee met at nine— Went to the Bank— President Biddle, Cadwalader Binney and M. Eyre there—

Statements by the President, with exhibition of Documents. Mr Clayton reads his written charges— Then part of the printed Indictment Counts— Biddle’s Explanations— M’Duffie insists upon examining the charge against the President, and
Psalm 93.

lg.l: Jehovah reigns—with glory clad
And girt with strength around—
The world is at his presence glad
Firm stands the solid ground
Establish’d is thy throne of Old
From everlasting Time
The floods to thee their waves have roll’d
And speak with voice sublime
The floods have lifted up their voice—
The billows of the Sea
The Lord—exclaiming they—Earth, rejoice
Is mightier far than we
Thy Testimonies, Lord, are sure
Thy Mercies are divine
Thy house forever shall endure—
And holiness is thine

div.p: Cashier of Norfolk-Branch— Adjourned from 2 to 5. Walk to the extremity of Chesnut Street, beyond Colonnade row— Met Randall—Mr Waln and Stout. Dined at four— Meeting at our Room from 5 to 8. Mr Cowperthwait Second Assistant Cashier— Examination of the Charges against the President, and Cashier of the Norfolk Branch. Mackintosh’s charges against Newton and Roberts— Cowperthwait’s Statements and explanations.— Adjourned to Monday Morning at nine. Fireman’s Ball declined. Also to deliver Oration 30. July next to Philomathean Society.
Letter to L. C. Adams. T. W. Dyot Glass-manufacturer here this morning
25. V:45. Sunday. Psalm 94.

lg.l: Jehovah, God of Vengeance—rise
O God of Vengeance, speak aloud
Rule from thy Mansion in the skies
Reward, as they deserve—the proud—
How long shall godless men—O Lord—
How long shall sway, the godless host—
How long despise thy holy word?
How long shall Evildoers boast—
They crush thy people at their will—
Thy choice inheritance oppress
The widow and the Stranger kill
And put to death the fatherless
And Tish—say they, God cannot see
It shall escape Jehovah’s eyes
O, blind and stupid, when will ye
When, O ye fools, will ye be wise?

div.p: With Mr Cowperthwait, at the Unitarian Church—heard Mr. Cunningham 2. Corinthians 3.6. The Letter killeth, and the Spirit giveth life.— In the Evening half past 7. at Church again— Mr John Vaughan came home with me. Found Jos. M’Ilvaine and Josiah Randall with Mr M’Duffie— Note from Madame Lingu, who says she became acquainted with me at Vienna in Austria—where I never was.
26. V:30. Monday.

lg.l: Shall he who made the eye be blind?
Shall he be deaf who form’d the ear?
Shall not the teacher of mankind
Be felt in punishment severe?
The thoughts of men, Jehovah knows,
With Vanity and falsehood fraught
And blest, in thy chastising blows
The man, by thy Instruction taught.
Till in the pit the godless fall
Patience in evil-days to take—
The Lord shall hear his People call—
Nor his inheritance forsake—
To Judgment, Justice shall return
Follow’d by all the true in heart.
The wicked, who with me shall spurn?
Against them, who with me take part?

div.p: Committee met at 9. A.M. At the Bank— Explanations by the President and Documents— Loan to James Watson Webb— His Letter to Mr. Cambreleng— Anonymous letter to Mr Thomas— Erasure and pen-crossings— Book of Bills issued and discounts. Letters to the Cashiers of Branches. Branch Bank of Baltimore, and the Bank of Maryland. Mr Poultney President.— Adjourned after 3— Walk. My Colleagues went to the Theatre, Changed my Chamber. Letters—one from L. C. Adams.
27. VI. Tuesday.

lg.l: But that the Lord assistance gave
My Soul in Silence had been laid
My foot just sinking in the grave
Thy Mercy was at hand to save
In all the sorrows of my heart
My Soul, from thee, shall comfort draw
Wilt thou with evil’s throne take part?
And sanction wickedness by Law.
Against the righteous, lo they flock
The blood of Innocence they shed—
But though, Jehovah, art my Rock
Thy saving Mercy shields my head.
Their sins, Jehovah shall reward.
In their own malice they shall fall
Their evil deeds provoke the Lord.
His Anger shall destroy them all.

div.p: At the Bank from ten to four. Mackintosh’s charges upon the President and Cashier of the Norfolk-Branch Bank. After going through with them Mr Clayton’s moves to send to him for papers—agreed and then to subpoena him to appear here 10. April This last motion carried by Clayton—Cambreleng—R. M. Johnson—Thomas—

Nays Adams, M’Duffie, and Watmough. Then reconsidered. To send for the papers, first; and afterwards for him to Washington. Adjourned at 4. J. S. Hastings here after dinner—going on to Boston, N. Biddle going to-morrow to Washington— Call at J. Connell’s— W. B. Hodgson sent up a Card— Letter to L. C. A.
28. V:45. Wednesday— Psalm 95

lg.l: Come—let us sing unto the Lord.
The rock of our Salvation sing
With joyful noise his praise record
And Thanks before his presence bring.
Great is Jehovah— Great our God
Exalted above all, his throne
The depths of Earth obey his nod
The Mountain-tops are all his own
He made the Sea. The Land he made.
And both his matchless power reveal
O, be the Lord our God obey’d
O come, before him let us kneel—
He is our maker—we his flock—
His people, by his Pasture fed
Let not your hearts be turn’d to rock—
O, hear his warning voice with dread—

div.p: W. Findlay and Dr Moore. Visit to the Mint. Coll Walbach. Met in Committee at the Bank—examined two Clerks of the Bank—concerning notes of James Watson Webb and Silas E. Burrows— Mr Cambreleng offers a Resolution to Subpoena them—which at my Motion was postponed— Left examination unfinished— Visits after dinner to T. L. M’Kenny— To Mrs Roberdeau and her daughters and to judge Hopkinson. Met Count Survilliers and his nephew.
29. VI. Thursday.

lg.l: As in the Wilderness of yore
Your wandering Sires, my Patience tried
With rebel hearts my precepts bore
And forty years my will defied.
At length I said—this Stubborn race,
Can never with my Law be blest.
And sware, with wrath, averted face
They never should enjoy my rest.

div.p: Psalm 96:

lg.l: Sing to Jehovah’s name a song
O sing,—all ye, on Earth who dwell
With joyful voice his praise prolong—
And daily his Salvation tell
His glory throughout Earth proclaim
His power to all mankind display
Great is Jehovah’s glorious name—
Far above other Gods his sway

div.p: Committee at the Bank. Further Examination of the Discounts and Notes of James Watson Webb, Mordecai M. Noah; and Silas E. Burrows. Examination of Clerks continued. Examination of John Bohlen,—Director— Minute Suspicions. Erasures— diversity of ink

Afternoon call at C. J. Ingersoll’s. Visit to W. Meredith—one of my brother Thomas’s Intimates—now an old man— C. C. Biddle. Free-trademan— Madame Lingu—thought she had seen me at Vienna. La Lande box of minerals from Andrew Armstrong at Lima.
Judge Baldwin and Madame Lingu.
30. VI. Friday.

lg.l: To Idols, all the Nations bow
But he, Jehovah made the skies—
To him let Israel pay the vow—
To him let Judah’s incense rise—
Before him Power and Honour go
Beauty and Glory gird his throne—
To him, let streams of rapture flow.
O worship him, and him alone.
O Earth, give glory to his name
Come, to his Courts your tribute bring
His praise in holy garb proclaim—
Proclaim the Lord Jehovah King.
Earth in her orbit stedfast rolls
Guided by his almighty hand
He too, the ways of man controuls
And rules in Righteousness the Land

div.p: Dr. S. Moore and Govr. Findlay here— We went with them to the new Mint Building— Not yet finished—
Committee met at the Bank. Still on the Discounts to James Watson Webb. Silas E. Burrows and M. M. Noah— Examination ofNeff a director and also of the second Assistant Cashier—

Captious Questions— Adjourned at 3. O’Clock— I wrote to my Son Charles— J. Connell here after dinner— Evening at the Library of the Philosophical Society. C. C. Biddle— Harlan, Hopkinson, Walsh there— Connell’s third opinion of Dermot favourable.
31. VI. Saturday.

lg.l: Ye Heavens be glad—let Earth rejoice
Roar, with thy fastness, boundless deep—
Let every Field lift up her voice
Ye forests, joyous revels keep—
He comes, he comes, the Lord of all
He comes his judgments to display
Ye Nations, down before him fall
For Truth and Justice mark his way.

div.p: Psalm 97.

lg.l: Jehovah reigns— Earth raise the song
Ye Islands, all, repeat the strain
Around him, Clouds and Darkness throng
Justice and Truth his Throne sustain
Resistless fire before him goes
His Lightnings flash the world around
Their scorching blasts consume his foes—
Earth trembles—shakes the solid ground.

div.p: Cave Johnson and Mardis— At the Bank— Examined Directors Cope and Bevan— Still upon James Watson Webb—M. M. Noah—and Silas E. Burrows— I proposed after hearing the President Biddle to close this Examination— It was voted. Clayton, Johnson, Cambreleng, Thomas—vs. Adams, M’Duffie and Watmough, to Subpoena Webb I called for Webb’s Letter to Cambreleng, which was produced. I asked for the anonymous Letter to Thomas—he said it was destroy’d. discussion thereupon—adjourned at 1/2 past 3.— Clayton dined with us. Cave Johnson, Mardis and R. Peters after dinner. F. A. Packard on Sunday School Union. Mr Nicklin here— Evening at his house.
